Opposition politicians are calling on B.C. Premier John Horgan to reduce the tax load on forest companies as they deal with log shortages, slumping lumber prices and continued import duties from the United States.

B.C. Liberal leader Andrew Wilkinson and forests critic John Rustad released a letter to Horgan on Thursday, calling for reduction of carbon tax charged to forest companies, and stumpage fees collected by the province for harvesting of timber from Crown land.

"John Horgan needs to hold himself accountable, stop making excuses and stop the job losses in this province," Rustad said. "At a time when forestry workers across the province should be hard at work, instead they are facing job losses and no paycheques."

Forests Minister Doug Donaldson said Thursday the province must proceed carefully on any changes to B.C. stumpage is well known to incite protests from U.S. lumber producers, who have argued for decades that B.C.'s lumber is subsidized by artificially low cost of logs.

"Messing with the stumpage system is not a solution," Donaldson told Black Press.

Donaldson also noted that during his bried time as forests minister in 2017, Rustad predicted up to 10 mills closing due to the decline in timber supply due to pine beetle damage.

Canfor, Interfor, West Fraser, Tolko and other lumber producers have announced temporary and permanent mill closures across the province in recent weeks, citing the scarcity of sawlogs in the B.C. Interior and a long slide in prices for construction lumber in recent months.

The downturn has spread to oriented strandboard producers. Louisiana Pacific announced Thursday it is shutting down its OSB production facility in Taylor, B.C. in August, after a similar announcement by Norbord for its OSB plant in 100 Mile House earlier this week.

RELATED: Norbord shutdown affects 160 workers in 100 Mile House

RELATED: Canfor temporarily shutting down sawmills across B.C.

Wilkinson and Rustad are calling on the B.C. government to reduce stumpage and carbon tax on forest companies, their logging contractors and other businesses that depend on the forest industry "until market conditions stabilize."

Their suggestions include creating a fund for communities hit by the recent closures and curtailments, to put laid-off employees to work on wildfire prevention projects. Fuel load from decades of forest fire suppression has been a factor in recent record fire seasons.

Wildfire prevention projects are being funded and federal and provincial governments are working together to provide "short-term support for workers and communities," Donaldson said.

(CP) _ Officials are watching for anyone who needs stress counselling as residents of this fire-threatened area in southwestern Alberta return home from being evacuated.</p><p nitf:lede="true">While the 1,200 residents of Blairmore are relieved to be home, municipal and health officials are watching for anyone who may have suffered psychological stress because of the fire threat and evacuations, said Crowsnest Pass Mayor John Irwin.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>"Once the crisis ends and the adrenaline quits flowing there's sort of a sense a staggered sense of collapse,'' Irwin said. "People find difficulty coping for a period of time.''</p><p>Blairmore is one of five communities that make up Crowsnest Pass, which is located about 250 kilometres southwest of Calgary.</p><p>Residents have been through quite an ordeal as they returned home Sunday evening after firefighters managed to contain the nearby Lost Creek blaze.</p><p>It was the second time in just more than a week that residents had to flee their homes as the out-of-control fire came within two kilometres of their community.</p><p>During the first evacuation, an additional 800 people from nearby Hillcrest were also forced to leave their homes on an hour's notice. They however, were spared from having to go through the ordeal again.</p><p>The massive fire, which has burned for nearly a month and blackened more than 210 square kilometres, is no longer deemed out of control and is being held, said fire information officer Marvin Doran.</p><p>"It's been a long haul trying to get a grip on it,'' said Doran. "But after long hours, we are now able to get into the hot spots within the perimeter of the fire and work on putting them out.</p><p>"In the last three days the fire hasn't made any gains,'' said Doran, adding 900 firefighters, 26 helicopters, 35 bulldozers and 78 water tank vehicles all continue to battle the blaze.</p><p>Residents remain on a one-hour evacuation alert just in case the fire burns out of control again.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20030818CPCPD8022</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2003</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:49BG-BT90-01G6-917G-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="319"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2003 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="18" month="08" year="2003"><dateText>August 18, 2003 Monday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>SOCIAL; urn:contentItem:5P6D-YR41-F105-603T-00000-00More international firefighters deployed to battle B.C. wildfires2017-08-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:40ZLexisNexisNEWSMore international firefighters deployed to battle B.C. wildfires

To ensure that adequate resources are available during B.C.'s wildfire fight, more international personnel are on the way.

Over the next week, more than 400 firefighting staff from New Zealand, Australia, Mexico and the U.S. will join the more than 3,800 personnel currently working throughout the province to respond to the ongoing wildfire situation in B.C.

"Given the unprecedented nature of the B.C. wildfires, we appreciate the assistance our international partners are able to provide," said Doug Donaldson, forests minister.

There will be a mix of specialized support staff, including incident management teams, and highly trained and experienced wildland firefighting crews. They will join more than 3,150 personnel from British Columbia (including more than 1,450 B.C. contract personnel) as well as over 630 other out-of-province personnel who have been working tirelessly to protect the province's communities and infrastructure.

These firefighters are trained to the standards of the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre.

"Hot and dry weather conditions have kept a persistently high-to-extreme fire danger rating throughout B.C. Firefighting crews are on standby in all six of B.C.'s fire centres in preparation for an anticipated increase in fire starts over the next few days due to unsettled weather in the forecast that may bring lightning," states a release.

Khandekar</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Dear Editor - Re: ' Forest fires wild cards in Kyoto strategy,' (Guelph Mercury, Mar. 4)</p><p nitf:lede="true">I would like to correct Brian Stocks, a forest fire expert from Sault St. Marie who was recently quoted as saying "with climate change, we know we are going to see more fires and more forest area burned in the future..."</p><p nitf:lede="true">In reality, there is little evidence to support the idea that forest fires are related to climate change or global warming, as many environmentalists would like us to believe.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Forest fires are primarily initiated by lightening discharges from thunderstorms.</p><p>Human activity responsible for forest fires relates to outdoor camping and use of open fires. Forest fire activities in Western Canada and in particular in British Columbia show considerable inter-annual variation, some of this variability being linked to the ENSO (El Nino-Southern Oscillation) phase in the equatorial eastern Pacific.</p><p>At the Canadian Prairie drought workshop in Calgary in May 2004 ( I organized the workshop on behalf of Alberta Environment), Dr. Brian Amiro, a forest fire expert at the Canadian Forestry Service and now with the University of Manitoba, suggested in his presentation that inter-annual variability in forest fire activity makes it difficult to identify any linkage with climate change.</p><p>With so many variables to consider, and much debate taking place as to the cause of both forest fires and global climate change, it is extremely premature to link the two.</p><p>Madhav L. And joining us now<br/>with the dish on the concert buzz, because it was last night, is<br/>Susie Wall, eTalk entertainment reporter.</p><p nitf:lede="true">WALL: Hi.</p><p nitf:lede="true">THOMSON: It was a great concert. We just saw a little bit of<br/>that. Can you tell us a little bit about the concert?</p><p>WALL: Well, it was fantastic. And, as you know, it hasn't been<br/>the easiest year for British Columbians, especially those affected<br/>by the fires. And so that makes this story all that much more<br/>heart-warming. Two Canadian boys coming home, Bryan Adams and<br/>Colin James, for this fantastic concert. They gave four nights of<br/>concert donations. So they're hoping to raise $200,000 to go<br/>towards the efforts, which is fantastic. And, you know, Bryan<br/>Adams could be playing anywhere in the world right now, and he was<br/>here at home.</p><p>THOMSON: Yeah, he really could. And it's amazing. Huge names,<br/>as you said, to raise an awful lot of money. But speaking of Bryan<br/>Adams, while he's here, there's an awful lot of scandal or<br/>controversy or whatever you want to call it. What do you know? Or<br/>what's the latest on that?</p><p>WALL: Well, reportedly, Bryan Adams denies this affair with<br/>Diana, this scandalous affair, after her breakup with Charles. But<br/>who's to know? He's been linked with some of the most beautiful<br/>women in the world, including Gwyneth Paltrow. We've all seen that<br/>shot of them on the scooter and outside of a London restaurant.<br/>But he definitely has that star quality, which makes him all the<br/>more appealing to us as Canadians because he's a good ol' Burnaby<br/>boy. You know what? He's home, and it's fantastic.</p><p>THOMSON: Yeah, which is great. And speaking of star quality,<br/>another good ol' Vancouver boy is Michael Buble. And it was great,<br/>I got a chance to sit down and talk to him. He's a very powerful<br/>singer, a crooner type like Frank Sinatra. But he's also a really<br/>interesting guy. Here's our talk.</p><p>[Taped segment begins]</p><p>THOMSON: You still choose Vancouver as home. What is it about<br/>this place?</p><p>BUBLE: Well, I was born here. So it's kind of a natural thing<br/>for me to love it and be biased in that way. But I honestly think<br/>that it's got to be one of the most beautiful cities in the world.</p><p>THOMSON: How much is Michael Buble? I mean, people hear the<br/>crooner, that type of voice, all the stuff, Dean Martin, that kind<br/>of thing. Are they surprised when they meet you? Because you're<br/>not exactly like Frank Sinatra.</p><p>BUBLE: I'm not at all like Frank Sinatra. No, I think that<br/>people have a definite image of who I should be, because of the<br/>music. No, I'm not at all. I think some people are enthused that<br/>I'm young and that I'm a punk and that I'm an immature, you know,<br/>drinkin', partyin', woman-loving, very regular 28-year-old kid. I<br/>refuse to pretend to be something I'm not.<br/></p><p>No record company would touch me. I think that what happened was<br/>I think the public made enough noise that they wanted to hear great<br/>music. They wanted to hear music with substance. I think that<br/>melody was lost. I think that great lyrics had been lost for a<br/>while.</p><p>THOMSON: So what's the next step for Michael Buble?</p><p>BUBLE: I'd like very much to be a dad. I'd like to have kids.<br/>And I've got to show you this [picture from his wallet] just for a<br/>second. Sorry, my wallet's very George Costanza-ish.</p><p>THOMSON: [laughs] That's okay.</p><p>BUBLE: This is my little nephew. My little sister is 24 and she<br/>just had this little boy. His name is O'Shea[ph].</p><p>THOMSON: Oh, how sweet is that!</p><p>BUBLE: This is the only thing I don't like about going on the<br/>road. I miss him and I miss my parents and my grandparents. But<br/>I want that. I'm working very hard in my life so that I can have<br/>this and I can give them a good life.<br/></p><p>And, like I said to you before, I do not base success on my job.<br/>My job is not who I am. My dad and my grandpa never had a million<br/>dollars and they never sold one record, and they're easily the most<br/>successful people I know. And so, if I can go that route that'll<br/>be good for me.</p><p>[Taped segment ends]</p><p>THOMSON: Susie, I found it was a real dichotomy. One the one<br/>hand, he's saying his recipe for success, which is so charming, and<br/>on the other he's saying, you know, "I'm just a punk". He's an<br/>amazing fellow.</p><p>WALL: I would classify him, too, as a charmer. He's a lovely<br/>guy. Everywhere Michael Buble goes people fall madly in love with<br/>him. And he's done so extremely well. It was just probably not<br/>200 feet from where we are right now on Granville Island where<br/>Michael performed his first paying gig at the Red Rock Diner at the<br/>Arts Club Theatre. That was the late '90s. Fast-forward a few<br/>years later, and he's really hit the world stage with a shebang.<br/>It's a great story.</p><p>THOMSON: Yeah, he's hugely successful and he was a delight and,<br/>as you say, charming to talk to.</p><p>WALL: Very much so.</p><p>THOMSON: Susie Wall, thank you for coming down and joining us on<br/>Granville Island this morning. MUSKOKA - (UPDATE: 2:45 p.m., Thursday, Aug. 9) The Muskoka Fire Danger Rating has dropped from "HIGH" to "MODERATE", according to Muskoka Lakes Fire Department.

The Fire Danger Rating has been dropped to Moderate. In @MuskokaLakesTwp Daytime burning is still prohibited unless you have a valid 2018 burning permit purchased through the Township office. @Muskoka411 @MuskokaLakes @MuskokaRatepyrs @MuskokaRegion @CTVBarrieNews #Muskoka - Muskoka Lakes FD (@MuskokaLakesFD) August 9, 2018

Muskoka had been under an extreme fire danger rating, meaning a complete fire ban, from Thursday, July 5 to Thursday, July 26 when it dropped to high. The rating is now set at moderate.

This means there is a moderate danger of fire. Daytime burning is not permitted in a moderate rating. Carry out permitted fire activities with caution.

For more information on what this means in your municipality, check local bylaws: Bracebridge, Gravenhurst, Huntsville, Muskoka Lakes, Lake of Bays, Georgian Bay. Call Toll Free 1-877-847-1577 for the up-to-date Muskoka Fire Danger Rating.

The Fire Danger Rating is now set at MODERATE - Small fires are permitted keeping in mind that NO DAYTIME BURNING is allowed (8am - 6pm). You must have adequate tools and water and you must be with your fire at all times. Please fully extinguish your fire when you are done. pic.twitter.com/TObhvmUjuK - HLOB Fire Department (@HLOBfire) August 9, 2018

The Muskoka Fire Danger Rating is determined using the Fire Weather Index (FWI), an internationally used method for determining the risk of fires in open air. It uses factors such as the relative humidity, temperature, previous 24-hour rain amount, wind directions and wind speed in combination with the forest fuel type and loads to determine the risk of the forest to certain fire types. From this calculation the Forest Fire Danger Rating is made in consultation with the fire chiefs of the six area municipalities and the Ministry of Natural Resources.

urn:contentItem:5WT7-V5N1-F103-300F-00000-00What's in the Bottle? Finding libations for the barbecue2019-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:40ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITYWhat's in the Bottle? Finding libations for the barbecue

Barbeque, BBQ, barbecue.

However you want to spell it, it's a great way to socialize with friends and family. But where did the idea come from?

Anthropologists believe that humans began eating cooked foods somewhere between 2 million and 300,000 years ago. Some experts theorize that the idea of cooked meat came from early man eating animals killed during a forest fire.

Barbecue, as we know it, was first practiced by aboriginal peoples as a method of preserving food. The first written record of this practice came in the late 15th century when Spanish explorers found Aboriginals in the Caribbean drying meat on a raised wooden rack with a small fire made with green wood creating smoke.

The idea was to preserve the meat by drying it and to keeping insects off the food with the smoke.

The Spanish loved the flavor and took this idea of cooking back to Spain.

Fast forward to the 19th century in the United States and the practice of cooking meat over a slow fire with lots of smoke had spread from Virginia, south to the Carolinas, north up the Mississippi, and of course resulting in four very distinct styles of barbecue.

Memphis is known for its pork shoulder in tomato-based sauce, the Carolinas use a vinegar-based sauce, Kansas City uses dry rubs, and Texas is all about the beef, especially the beef brisket.

The main theme for all of these styles is low heat, smoke, and time. Most Pit Masters today will BBQ for 12 to 14 hours. The goal is to take inexpensive cuts of meat, cook low and slow, and it will come out fork tender.

Most of us today grill, not really BBQ (except my friend Marty), be it a gas grill or charcoal. Yet we all have the same question, what kind of libations do we drink with it?

Recently I went down to see the Happy Fishermen at French Creek and asked about getting some fresh salmon. Even though the chinook fishery is limited there seems to be more fish than anticipated.

One of my favorite ways to grill salmon is on a cedar plank with a sweet teriyaki sauce, deliciously accompanied with a Pinot Noir. I found three pinots' that would do nicely. Kalala Vineyards from East Kelowna, La Crema from Sonoma County, and Aresti from Chile.

With steak and burgers, I gravitate to California Zinfandel and Spanish Rioja. These reds offer a lovely red fruit flavors, with a spicy quality brought on with oak aging.

If seafood is your favorite grilling fare, try a nice Pinot Gris, Pinot Grigio, or a fine Rose chilled on your veranda. Tomassi Pinot Grigio and Gheringer Pinot Gris are nice choices.

Cheers.

Peter Fenn is assistant manager of the Parksville North BC Liquor Store.

urn:contentItem:7VYK-CDT1-2R6R-50G7-00000-00Residents return home after part of B.C. forest fire evacuation order lifted2009-06-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:40ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSResidents return home after part of B.C. forest fire evacuation order liftedSUNNY DHILLONCP

VANCOUVER _ Some of the residents chased from their homes by a wild fire in the B.C. Interior have returned to their properties, while others might be out for quite some time.

An evacuation order for three communities affected by the Tyaughton Lake blaze, about 65 kilometres west of Lillooet, has been downgraded to an evacuation alert.

Leslie Lloyd, spokeswoman for the Squamish-Lillooet Regional District, said some residents and property owners of Tyaughton Lake, Gun Creek Road and Mud Creek went home Sunday.

''Certainly there was a collective sigh of relief and applause and appreciation and certainly the people are indicating that they're very happy to be permitted to return home,'' Lloyd said.

B.C. fire information officer Elise Riedlinger said crews have about half of the 80-square-kilometre Tyaughton Lake fire contained.

''The southwest and west flanks of the fire have been very quiet. They are holding the containment lines there, although they did have to work on putting out a few hot spots (Saturday),'' she said.

''Now their main focus is going to be on the north flank of the fire, as well as the east. This is an area with very steep, difficult terrain.''

Riedlinger said fire crews have been helped by cooler temperatures and lighter winds.

Evacuation orders remain in effect for three other communities and Riedlinger said that will remain the case for some time.

''It's not in the immediate future for Marshall Lake, Liza Lake and Carol Lake (residents to return home) because that fire is still so active on the ridge above Marshall Lake,'' she said.

Evacuation alerts also remain in place for Gun Lake, Gold Bridge, and Bralorne.

Several of the evacuees had been pushing the district to lift the evacuation order that was enforced for more than a week.

Lloyd said of the 75 evacuees, approximately 60 are from the three areas where Sunday's evacuation order was downgraded.

RCMP were on site to control the re-entry process. Information handouts were made available to those returning to the area to ensure they were aware of any potential hazards.

The Tyaughton Lake fire is believed to have been human caused.

Near the B.C.-Yukon border, fire crews continued their battle against the province's other major blaze.

The Smith River fire is about 230 square kilometres in size and is believed to have been caused by a lightning strike.

The fire is about 30 per cent contained and is being battled by 84 firefighters.

Three communities with a total population of about 15 people are on evacuation alert.

(CP) - Where Stan Byers' family home once stood in the gently rolling foothills of southern Alberta, all that remains is a smoldering pile of black ash, a propane tank and some charred farm machinery.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"It's kind of an eerie feeling to look at yourself and all you've got is a couple of vehicles, the coats you walked out with,'' a dejected Byers, 75, said Monday, a day after RCMP dragged him from the wildfire that destroyed his property.</p><p nitf:lede="true">People in the area watched helplessly as a voracious prairie fire, pushed by strong warm winds, roared across a 100-square-kilometre stretch of land Sunday, creating a black scar acorss the golden-brown Prairie.</p><p>The grass fire was largely contained Monday, although there was still a large blaze burning in the Porcupine Hills region.</p><p>In northern Alberta, two huge forest fires were still burning out of control in the west-central region around Hinton, though they did not appear to threaten populated areas.</p><p>One near the community of Entrance was about 500 hectares, said Rick Strickland of Alberta Lands and Forest Service. The larger blaze southeast of Hinton was 1,500 hectares.</p><p>"There was infrared scanning done last night to isolate the hot spots so resources can be deployed to those areas,'' said Strickland. "The wind did allow us to get some aircraft in the air.''</p><p>The grasslands of southern Alberta are tinder dry and there is no snow cover. That gave the fire an enormous amount of fuel with nothing but open prairie in front of it.</p><p>A lifetime of Byers' memories was consumed by the wall of flame as it rolled down a ridge to the west of his 95-year-old home.</p><p>"It was home-sweet-home until Sunday, now there's nothing,'' said Byers, who lived there with his wife Clara and son Jim.</p><p>The fire forced the evaucation of Granum, about 120 kilometres south of Calgary, for a short time Sunday as the flames threatened to jump Highway 2 - the province's main four-lane divided highway running north-south.</p><p>The only injury reported was on Big Coulee Ranch immediately west of Elgin's property, where 80-year-old Frieda Kaiser was hurt trying to escape smoke and fire Sunday.</p><p>Dave Claypool, a councillor with the Municipal District of Willowcreek, said Kaiser was attempting to reach a pond adjacent to the house when her dress caught fire.</p><p>She was taken by air ambulance to Calgary Foothills Hospital where she was in stable condition Monday, recovering from second- and third-degree burns.</p><p>Byers' home was one of the last to be consumed by the blaze before firefighters got it under control just outside the village.</p><p>Near the house, they continued to douse hotspots Monday as a string of telephone poles lay on their side - burned off at the bottom.</p><p>At a nearby Hutterite colony, the burned-out shells of feed storage buildings still spewed smoke and machinery sat scorched in a field.</p><p>Without a drastic change in the weather - some snow or rain and calm winds - fires could flare up again, fire officials said.</p><p>Residents of Granum were praising firefighters for stopping the flames before they could reach the tiny community of 350 people. Residents worked alongside firefighters from several departments in southern Alberta to battle the blaze.</p><p>Several people gathered in the community's drop-in centre Monday over coffee to exchange stories.</p><p>Eileen Cesar said when the call came to leave Granum she grabbed her asthmatic grandson, the rest of her family and some new neighbors to form a four-car convoy out of town.</p><p>"I took a look around and I thought as long as the family was all together, you know where they were at, the rest can be replaced,'' she said.</p><p>"But my heart aches for the ones who lost so much, we're all still a little shocked.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5W8R-TW61-F103-315P-00000-00Forecasters watching for June rain after West Kootenay's driest May in 24 years2019-06-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:40ZLexisNexisNEWSForecasters watching for June rain after West Kootenay's driest May in 24 years

May was a great month for planning outdoor events in our area, but the dry, sunny weather is getting a little worrisome.

Weather forecasters at the Southeast Fire Centre in Castlegar say their records show May was the driest in a quarter-century. And it follows two other months that had lower-than-usual precipitation.

"It was definitely dry," says Ron Lakeman, a weather forecaster at the Southeast Fire Centre. "We have definitely been at a deficit in the last few months."

The total amount of rain in May was only 23.7 millimetres, or 34 per cent of normal. It was the third driest May on record. Only May of 1970 and 1995 were drier.

The cause of the dry weather was an upper ridge of high pressure centred off the coast at the start of the month, then over the interior. It dominated with dry and warmer trending conditions during the initial two weeks of May.

A large Pacific system followed but generally missed the West Kootenay, with light amounts of rain from the 14th to 17th. The only other measurable rainfall during the month was the 12.6 millimetres on the 24th and 25th.

High pressure dominated for dry and unseasonably warm conditions again during the final five days of the month.

Impact on forest fires

But while May didn't help relieve the rain deficit, Lakeman says it's what happens in the next few weeks that's important for forest fire season.

"Rainfall in May is not one of the crucial months" when it comes to forest fires, he says. "June, July and August are the mains."

Lakeman notes that of the two previous driest Mays, 1995 had no significant fire season, while 1970 did.

So he's keeping a close eye on the skies for the next week or so, when two systems are forecast to bring some rain to the region.

"If that's the start of something wetter, then there's relief on the horizon," he says. "But if the [high-pressure] ridge rebuilds and sticks, or the next system misses us, the deficit we have right now in terms of precipitation can certainly have some ramification coming into the crucial months of June, July and August.

"To get some precipitation over the next four weeks will have a large influence as to what things are like as we go through the heart of the summer."

Not only was it dry, but it was a warm month as well. The hottest day was the 29th, when the mercury hit 31.4 degrees. The coldest temperature was 1.6 degrees, hit on the 3rd.

No temperature records were broken this month.

A4</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Police officers' protest has grown into 'a forest fire'</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By David Lewis Stein Toronto Star</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>Police officers trooped out of their meeting last night vowing they would continue their protest job action and swearing they were 100 per cent behind Chief William McCormack - even though he has charged over 2,000 officers, almost half the uniformed police force, for breaking regulation.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But I believe McCormick went to that meeting only to keep alive rumors - false as far I can find out - that police board chair Susan Eng is trying to get him fired.</p><p nitf:lede="true">What began as a job protest a week ago has grown into what one police officer told me is "a forest fire."</p><p nitf:lede="true">But why now?</p><p>The beginnings probably owe more to internal power struggles among the police than to new regulations being imposed by Queen's Park.</p><p>The decision to, in effect, go on strike was taken last Sunday at a poorly publicized and poorly attended meeting of the Metro Police Association, the police union.</p><p>It was the day after the funeral of respected former chief Jack Ackroyd. Also, many officers had been told to be on call for possible duty at the Blue Jays game.</p><p>So only about 400 officers attended. Union president Art Lymer was in charge. But a group of militants took over.</p><p>They were from downtown divisions and they were protesting against new regulations requiring them to file reports every time they take their guns out of their holsters.</p><p>They also objected to the special investigations unit, a civilian body that investigates instances of police use of force.</p><p>The 400 union members decided that all of Metro's 5,500 uniformed police officers should break police regulations by taking off numbered identification badges and declining to write parking tickets until Premier Bob Rae meets with them.</p><p>The officers who started this thought they had legitimate grievances. But I have no doubt they also wanted to show fellow officers that they are the people to get action, not Art Lymer.</p><p>Lymer is certainly vulnerable. He defeated president Paul Walter in 1988 and in 1991, when Walter tried for a comeback, Lymer barely defeated him.</p><p>That year, foreseeing hard times ahead, Metro unions went for two-year contracts with 4.75 per cent pay increases each year. Lymer went for a one-year contract and 4.96 per cent.</p><p>But this year, the police are about to go into arbitration and they will be lucky to get more than 2.5 per cent.</p><p>Even worse, from the point of view of many officers, the police have been encroached upon during Lymer's tenure.</p><p>They say Premier Bob Rae not only listens to people who call the police racists and murderers, he has appointed some of them to a committee on new police regulations.</p><p>Worst of all, he has made the outspoken Susan Eng head of the police services board.</p><p>These things are not, of course, Art Lymer's fault.</p><p>But they happened during his watch. He is being blamed.</p><p>So even though Lymer himself did not appear to be in favor of the job action, he was not about to force any kind of showdown with the militants.</p><p>In fact, Lymer had received a letter telling him the Rae government was compromising on at least some things.</p><p>The written reports on unholstering guns would be used for statistical purposes only, not for disciplining officers, and Rae would try to get a more rational balance on his civilian committee dealing with police regulations.</p><p>If that letter had been read out last Sunday, it might have persuaded police that it wasn't necessary to break their own rules en masse in order to get Bob Rae to listen to them. But the letter was barely mentioned.</p><p>Instead, the meeting of 400 officers voted for the job action.</p><p>On Monday, the police services board met and rather than demanding disciplinary action, the board supported the police demands for a meeting with Rae.</p><p>Lymer had Eng and Metro Chairman Alan Tonks supporting him. It would have been a perfect time to end the job action.</p><p>Instead, Lymer let it go on.</p><p>On Wednesday, McCormack ordered the men to follow regulations. They defied him. He started charging officers.</p><p>A rumor swept the city that Eng had demanded McCormack's resignation. Officers swore that if McCormack went, they'd walk off the job.</p><p>The rumor turned out to be false. But now officers police are demanding Eng's resignation.</p><p>Rae is still refusing to meet with the union.</p><p>The police are headed for a showdown that nobody can win.Metropolitan; Toronto; urn:contentItem:5WS4-V581-JBTY-W3S8-00000-00Ontario sees huge drop in forest fires this year2019-08-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:40ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A7Ontario sees huge drop in forest fires this yearRob Ferguson Queen's Park Bureau

Ontario's forest fire season is much improved, with just one-third the number of blazes as last year at this time, but with changing conditions, officials are reminding campers and cottagers to keep their fires modest and to put them out at night.

In contrast to a hectic 2018 - when one persistent cottage-country fire near Parry Sound forced evacuations, jumped a CN rail line, came close to Hwy. 69 and sent dense smoke toward Sudbury and North Bay - there have been 373 forest fires to date.

"We have seen some more precipitation come through and a lot fewer fires caused by lightning," Shayne McCool, a fire information officer with the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry, told the Star from his office in Sudbury.

The 373 fires is a sharp drop from the 1,048 that had been reported or were burning at this point last year. The 10-year average is now 660 annually.

"We don't currently have any fires in the Parry Sound area, so that's certainly a good sign," McCool said Wednesday.

That fire last summer, officially known as Parry Sound 33, occupied as many as 500 specially trained forest firefighters daily at its peak. Other massive blazes stretched from the North Bay area up to Temagami and left 12,000 hectares of Lady Evelyn-Smoothwater Provincial Park in flames.

Conditions were so hazardous a year ago that open fires were restricted along a line stretching more than 300 kilometres westward from the Ontario-Quebec boundary near North Bay to Sault Ste. Marie, straight north and across to Timmins and Kirkland Lake.

It was the worst fire season in more than a decade and came with a firefighting price tag of almost $208 million.

McCool warned dryer, windier and less-humid conditions south of Sudbury and to the west are making that region "an area of concern" as the summer vacation season continues.

"Many of our fires are caused by unextinguished campfires, so we would like to remind the public to choose their site carefully when they are preparing to have a fire," he said.

That means making sure there is a water bucket or hose nearby, that the spot is sheltered from wind so sparks don't fly and that the fire is built on bare rock or soil.

To put out a fire, soak it with water, use a stick to uncover any hot embers and soak them again - and never leave a campfire unattended, McCool added.

The only fire not under control in the province is in the Sioux Lookout district. It has burned through 333 hectares.

Conditions are generally dryer in northwestern Ontario, where there are now 33 fires on the go, compared with just two in northeastern Ontario.

A4</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Police officers' protest has grown into 'a forest fire'</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BY DAVID LEWIS STEIN TORONTO STAR</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"> Police officers trooped out of their meeting last night vowing they would continue their protest job action and swearing they were 100 per cent behind Chief William McCormack - even though he has charged over 2,000 officers, almost half the uniformed police force, for breaking regulation.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But I believe McCormick went to that meeting only to keep alive rumors - false as far I can find out - that police board chair Susan Eng is trying to get him fired.</p><p nitf:lede="true">What began as a job protest a week ago has grown into what one police officer told me is "a forest fire."</p><p nitf:lede="true">But why now</p><p nitf:lede="true">The beginnings probably owe more to internal power struggles among the police than to new regulations being imposed by Queen's Park.</p><p>The decision to, in effect, go on strike was taken last Sunday at a poorly publicized and poorly attended meeting of the Metro Police Association, the police union.</p><p>It was the day after the funeral of respected former chief Jack Ackroyd. Also, many officers had been told to be on call for possible duty at the Blue Jays game.</p><p>So only about 400 officers attended. Union president Art Lymer was in charge. But a group of militants took over.</p><p>They were from downtown divisions and they were protesting against new regulations requiring them to file reports every time they take their guns out of their holsters.</p><p>They also objected to the special investigations unit, a civilian body that investigates instances of police use of force.</p><p>The 400 union members decided that all of Metro's 5,500 uniformed police officers should break police regulations by taking off numbered identification badges and declining to write parking tickets until Premier Bob Rae meets with them.</p><p>The officers who started this thought they had legitimate grievances. But I have no doubt they also wanted to show fellow officers that they are the people to get action, not Art Lymer.</p><p>Lymer is certainly vulnerable. He defeated president Paul Walter in 1988 and in 1991, when Walter tried for a comeback, Lymer barely defeated him.</p><p>That year, foreseeing hard times ahead, Metro unions went for two-year contracts with 4.75 per cent pay increases each year. Lymer went for a one-year contract and 4.96 per cent.</p><p>But this year, the police are about to go into arbitration and they will be lucky to get more than 2.5 per cent.</p><p>Even worse, from the point of view of many officers, the police have been encroached upon during Lymer's tenure.</p><p>They say Premier Bob Rae not only listens to people who call the police racists and murderers, he has appointed some of them to a committee on new police regulations.</p><p>Worst of all, he has made the outspoken Susan Eng head of the police services board.</p><p>These things are not, of course, Art Lymer's fault.</p><p>But they happened during his watch. He is being blamed.</p><p>So even though Lymer himself did not appear to be in favor of the job action, he was not about to force any kind of showdown with the militants.</p><p>In fact, Lymer had received a letter telling him the Rae government was compromising on at least some things.</p><p>The written reports on unholstering guns would be used for statistical purposes only, not for disciplining officers, and Rae would try to get a more rational balance on his civilian committee dealing with police regulations.</p><p>If that letter had been read out last Sunday, it might have persuaded police that it wasn't necessary to break their own rules en masse in order to get Bob Rae to listen to them. But the letter was barely mentioned.</p><p>Instead, the meeting of 400 officers voted for the job action.</p><p>On Monday, the police services board met and rather than demanding disciplinary action, the board supported the police demands for a meeting with Rae.</p><p>Lymer had Eng and Metro Chairman Alan Tonks supporting him. It would have been a perfect time to end the job action.</p><p>Instead, Lymer let it go on.</p><p>On Wednesday, McCormack ordered the men to follow regulations. They defied him. He started charging officers.</p><p>A rumor swept the city that Eng had demanded McCormack's resignation. Officers swore that if McCormack went, they'd walk off the job.</p><p>The rumor turned out to be false. But now officers police are demanding Eng's resignation.</p><p>Rae is still refusing to meet with the union.</p><p>The police are headed for a showdown that nobody can win.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">TSTAR1992</dc:source><dc:identifier And they are going to see for the first<br/>time the damage caused by the forest fires. Officials have added<br/>five homes to the gutted list, boosting that number destroyed to<br/>253. Not everyone, though, got out when the evacuation orders came<br/>down. One man refused to comply, and instead he stood his ground.</p><p>He looked the fires straight in the eye, with a little help from a<br/>pump and a lot of hose.<br/></p><p>CTV's Sarah Galashan has the story.</p><p>[Taped segment begins]</p><p>SARAH GALASHAN [CTV News]: He might just be the luckiest<br/>homeowner alive. Ed Fenwick and six of his buddies risked their<br/>lives last Friday night. They were ordered to evacuate, but<br/>instead signed waivers and vowed to save his home.</p><p>ED FENWICK [Homeowner]: The guys we had on the roof here, they<br/>never flinched, they just stood their ground and nailed it.</p><p>GALASHAN: Hitting a wall of flames that raced towards the<br/>waterfront property at speeds up to 120 kilometres per hour, wiping<br/>out the homes that stood on either side.</p><p>FENWICK: That house was already down and collapsed. Our white<br/>house up there was collapsed. Everything beyond that had gone.</p><p>GALASHAN: They attached hoses to small water pumps that fed from<br/>Okanagan Lake, providing enough water to stop the fire in its<br/>tracks. But not before they watched in horror as the home next<br/>door exploded in flames.<br/></p><p>In total, 248 hoses were destroyed by the fire. And while almost<br/>all of the fire refugees will return home by week's end, the loss<br/>makes this victory bittersweet.</p><p>FENWICK: Everybody was yelling, like, "The house is going! It's<br/>going!" And you feel sick because we couldn't reach that far with<br/>our hoses.</p><p>GALASHAN: At the height of it, their thoughts turned to the<br/>escape boats they had waiting in the water.</p><p>GORD BROWN [Friend]: We could've got off the roof if we had to.<br/>But we stuck it out because Eddie's our pal.</p><p>GALASHAN: They went well beyond the call of duty.</p><p>FENWICK: Well, I think we have proven that friends are the most<br/>valuable thing you can have.</p><p>GALASHAN: Thanks to them, he still has a million-dollar view and<br/>a home that's worth even more.</p><p>[Taped segment ends]</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CTV2003</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:49DF-M6N0-00RJ-F01M-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">211506</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-28</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="389"/><timeReceived>07:11:15 - urn:contentItem:5SHY-P291-DY9S-T3SW-00000-00Growing Colorado wildfire forces more evacuations2018-06-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:40ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONALGrowing Colorado wildfire forces more evacuationsGrowing Colorado wildfire forces more evacuationsThe Associated Press

DURANGO, Colo. - A growing wildfire burning in southwestern Colorado forced more people from their homes Sunday as crews tried to slow the blaze being fed by continued hot, dry and windy conditions.

Authorities ordered the residents of 675 homes to evacuate after the fire burning north of Durango nearly doubled in size overnight to 26 square miles (67 square kilometres).

Residents of a total of 2,156 homes have been ordered to evacuate as of Sunday afternoon, La Plata County spokeswoman Megan Graham told The Durango Herald.

No homes have been lost to the fire, which is 10 per cent contained.

The cause of the blaze, which is being called the 416 Fire, which started June 1 in the San Juan National Forest, has not been determined. It comes amid a severe drought in the Four Corners area where Arizona, New Mexico, Utah and Colorado meet.

Incident commander Todd Pechota told evacuated residents Saturday that the situation is "going to get worse before it gets better," the Herald reported.

A historic scenic railroad popular with tourists who come to area for hiking, camping and biking in the summer has stopped running because of the fire. The Durango & Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad is considering offering limited service later in the month with locomotives powered by diesel rather than its typical coal-fired engines, which can throw sparks.

The fire is the largest of several burning in Colorado, including another fire that broke out nearby Friday. Firefighters were able to respond quickly to another fire that started Saturday near Wolcott. Authorities there are asking for the public's help looking for three men seen leaving the area where it started.

Fire officials have been expecting a busy wildfire season after a dry winter, possibly the worst since 2012 and 2013, when the Black Forest Fire in El Paso County destroyed nearly 500 homes, the most in state history.

ATHABASCA NUCLEAR CORPORATION ("ASC-V") - Regulatory Decisions

Athabasca Nuclear Corporation ("Athabasca Nuclear" or the "Corporation") reports that the Government of Saskatchewan has granted regulatory relief to the Corporation (the "Regulatory Decisions") with respect to Athabasca Nuclear's Wollaston NE and Preston Projects (the "Properties") located in Northern Saskatchewan.

The Regulatory Decisions follow government reviews and legal submissions made by Athabasca Nuclear with respect to the unprecedented forest fire situation in Saskatchewan. Athabasca Nuclear reports that there is substantial forest fire activity and risk occurring where the Corporation's mineral tenure is located.

As a result of the Regulatory Decision, the Corporation advises that work requirements for the current assessment period at the Properties has been satisfied by way of regulatory relief. The approximate area for which relief has been granted is 209,000 hectares.

"Athabasca Nuclear stands with the Government of Saskatchewan in recognizing the gravity of the forest fires impacting Northern Saskatchewan. Our thoughts are with the affected communities and we commend the resilient spirit of the people of Saskatchewan and first responders. We believe the leadership displayed by the Government of Saskatchewan in ensuring that the mineral exploration industry minimizes its footprint during this sensitive period of time is well-founded. Moreover, we wish to acknowledge the Government of Saskatchewan's exemplary commitment to public safety," stated Ryan Kalt, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Athabasca Nuclear.

The Corporation advises that it may also receive further relief on additional mineral tenure.

Athabasca Nuclear Corporation (TSXV:ASC) is an exploration company focused primarily on uranium exploration near the Athabasca Basin in Saskatchewan, Canada, and other select opportunities. More information about Athabasca Nuclear and its projects may be found at www.athabascanuclear.com.

May 02, 2017( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) A psychiatrist with the University of Alberta is studying how the 2016 wildfire has affected the lives of children in Fort McMurray. Other studies are also being conducted regarding anxiety, depression and PTSD among those who lived through the ordeal. Dr. Vincent Agyapong is engaged in a two-year project[1] that will see him travel from Edmonton to Fort McMurray once a month to interview approximately 5,000 elementary and secondary school students.

Agyapong received a $500,000 grant to carry out his research.So far, the psychiatrist found about 80 percent of Fort McMurray residents experienced some sort of mental health problems right after the fire. This was expected. However Agyapong also found one-third of these people are still exhibiting mental health issues. After Agyapong first went to Fort McMurray in November, he found PTSD in adults had increased from 0.4 percent to 12.8 percent of the population after the fire. He is now studying the effect of the fire on children. Yesterday marked the one year anniversary of the beginning of the wildfire. A small brush fire spread, eventually consuming 600,000 hectares of forest. Except for emergency workers and other necessary personnel, the entire population of Fort McMurray was forced to flee. READ ALSO: Fort McMurray recovery from 2016 forest fire plods along[2] Luckily, there was only two deaths attributed to the fire. A 15-year-old girl and her stepmother's nephew were killed when their SUV struck a tractor-trailer while they were travelling to escape the fire. READ ALSO: Firefighter's daughter dies in crash fleeing Fort McMurray fire[3] Sandra Corbett is a resident of Fort McMurray and she is also a psychiatrist with Alberta Health Services in Fort McMurray. Officials recently announced they were going to do a controlled burn in the area and even though Corbett knew what was happening, the fire and smoke brought back memories of a year ago. And she was not alone. According to Corbett[4], usually people in the area contact mental health specialists about 1,000 times each year. Between May 10, 2016 and Mar. 8, 2017, individuals contacted Alberta Health Services 29,068 times. Another study revealed almost one in six of the 355 people who fought the fire, suffered some form of mental illness in the aftermath of the wildfire. In yet another study[5], it was estimated about 1,200 women in Fort McMurray were pregnant at the time the wildfire broke out. Neuro-scientist Gerlinde Metz, of the University of Lethbridge, is studying the effect of the fire on 200 mothers and their children. Previous studies have suggested pregnant women who suffer from stress caused by natural disasters deliver their babies earlier and their children tend to be overweight, develop high blood pressure and are at greater risk of getting type 2 diabetes. It is hoped the results of these studies will lead to better mental health services for the residents of Fort McMurray. (CP) - A wind-whipped forest fire in this popular park in southwestern Alberta closed a U.S. border crossing Wednesday and forced campers to flee.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Const. Natalie Portras of Waterton RCMP had to rouse a half-dozen Canada Customs officers from the Chief Mountain border crossing about 5:30 a.m. The approaching fire forced them to evacuate via the U.S.</p><p>-BODY- "The fire was probably a few (kilometres) away but it was coming fast,'' she said.</p><p>Lightning likely ignited the fire Saturday on Sofa Mountain in the southeastern part of the park which, with Glacier National Park in Montana, forms an international peace park that is considered a world heritage site.</p><p>Winds of up to 80 kilometres per hour pushed the fire eastward along the U.S.-Canada border, said park spokeswoman Janice Smith.</p><p>Smith didn't know how many campers were evacuated early Wednesday from Belly Creek campground, a primitive camping area and one of several in the park, but thought it was less than 50.</p><p>"Kind of a rude awakening in the morning, I guess, for those folks, although the ones I talked to were fascinated, actually,'' Smith said.</p><p>"They got a pretty up-close look at the fire as they were being evacuated. That fire is quite spectacular because it's crowning.''</p><p>Crowning means the fire is spreading by jumping from treetop to treetop.</p><p>Smith said park officials were letting the fire burn because it was too dangerous to fight on the ground. Water bombers, forced down by the high winds, made way for helicopters with water buckets.</p><p>"We would just love to see the wind die down so we could suppress this fire,'' said Smith.</p><p>Hot, dry conditions forced the province to issue a fire ban in the southwest.</p><p>Among those in the path of the fire were Cindy and Dennis Baker, living on the West Valley Ranch. The ranch covers 900 hectares and comes within 100 metres of the Chief Mountain Highway, which runs along the international border.</p><p>Cindy awoke to a phone call from a brother about 5:30 a.m. and saw the flames reflecting off Sofa Mountain.</p><p>"We figured it would be here in an hour and we thought we'd have to go but the wind changed to the southeast,'' she said. "We were saying some pretty heavy prayers this morning.''</p><p>A change in wind direction may have saved their sixth-generation ranch, which was founded in the 1890s.</p><p>Horsemen were sent up into the hills to move 800 cattle belonging to family and neighbors to safer ground. Neighbors were also standing by with horse trailers to move out animals if necessary.</p><p>The fire posed no danger to the town of Waterton, which sits inside the park, although heavy smoke hung over the picturesque resort community, Smith said.</p><p>Meanwhile, the extremely dry conditions led to a ban on traffic on all back-country roads and trails in Cypress Hills Interprovincial Park, which straddles the Alberta-Saskatchewan boundary.</p><p>"Under these very extreme fire hazard conditions, even a spark from the muffler of a car in the dry grass could start a fire that would spread rapidly and be extremely difficult to control,'' said park superintendent Brad Mason.</p><p>(Lethbridge Herald)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Six are still out of control.</p><p>Another large fire is about eight kilometres away from the Frances Lake campground, which is also north of Watson Lake along the Robert Campbell highway.</p><p>Hockin said that fire is burning away from the campground but that it is in a steep area that is hard for firefighters to access.</p><p>The four other fires that are still out of control are within 40 kilometres of Watson Lake.</p><p>But Hockin said they are all small fires _ one or two hectares in size _ and not headed for the town.</p><p>The forecast calls for a 60 per cent chance of rain Tuesday and officials hope that will reduce the extreme fire hazard in the southeastern Yukon.</p><p>Forest firefighting crews were also battling two man-made fires in the Teslin area on the weekend.</p><p>(Whitehorse Star)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier (CP) - The north-central Quebec village of Parent was eerie, dark and deserted today except for a handful of firefighters trying to control forest fires that turned day into night hundreds of kilometres away.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"We're doing what we can to save the village,'' said Gerard Lacasse, spokesman for Quebec's forest fire protection agency.</p><p>Thick, black smoke hovered over the province as far east as the Gaspe and so many calls were made to emergency services, firefighters, police and government officies across the province that authorities could not respond to real emergencies Monday night and provincial police issued a call for calm.</p><p>On Monday afternoon, the smoke darkened the sky so much over Roberval - on Lac-St-Jean 250 kilometres to the east - that it triggered the town's automated street lights and residents had to drive with their headlights on.</p><p>The 500 residents of Parent - located on the CN railway line from Abitibi to the St. Maurice valley - were forced to leave Monday but "there are 20 firemen still there trying to make sure they have homes to come back to,'' Lacasse said.</p><p>He said the nearest fire, which had destroyed 400 square kilometres, was still out of control and was closer to the village.</p><p>"It seems to have slowed down a bit,'' he said.</p><p>"The winds have changed and the weather is cooler. But we still can't get close to it.</p><p>"It has flames 50 metres high and you can't see anything the smoke is so thick.</p><p>"In fact there was so much smoke we thought the fire had spread 10 kilometres further than it really did.'' Bruno Lasante, who was among those forced to leave Parent, about 500 kilometres north of Montreal, said: "It was like the end of the world.</p><p>"The village was in total darkness and the low, black clouds were tinged with the rosy glow of the flames.</p><p>"I don't know how they can save the village.''</p><p>"If it goes, we lose everything. If they don't declare it a disaster zone so we get compensation, I might as well put a rope around my neck.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5GDC-69T1-JDV5-F2YG-00000-00Soldiers, foreign crews join battle against wildfires2015-07-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:40ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. A5Soldiers, foreign crews join battle against wildfiresJohn CotterThe Canadian Press

Soldiers began helping crews fight wildfires threatening communities in northern Saskatchewan on Wednesday, as other western provinces called in help from foreign countries.

About 360 troops were building fire guards and clearing brush near La Ronge and Montreal Lake.

Steve Roberts with Saskatchewan Wildfire Management said crews made some progress and better visibility allowed aircraft to dump water on some flames.

He said the fire situation across Western Canada is so busy it is a challenge for the provinces to get enough firefighters.

"As we started down the road with these fires, Alberta and British Columbia fire hazards escalated, the numbers of fires increased and they had community evacuations as well," Roberts said.

"That has stretched the availability of resources across the country."

Flames and thick smoke have forced an estimated 9,000 people from their homes in Saskatchewan. Crews from Quebec, Ontario, Newfoundland, New Brunswick and South Dakota have been helping out.

Roberts said the province was in discussions with the United States government about more crews coming north.

The La Ronge First Nation was also seeking volunteers to help fight fires, including evacuees.

The Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, which co-ordinates firefighting services, said Canada may have to seek more help from abroad.

The latest report on the agency website said major wildfires "have the potential to exhaust agency fire resources nationally."

"National resource levels are insufficient to meet occurring and anticipated wildland fire activity," it said.

Alberta said it was bringing in 62 firefighters from Mexico to help battle 92 wildfires. It was also looking at using crews from Australia and New Zealand.

British Columbia, with more than 180 fires, was bringing in firefighters from Australia. Forty properties were on evacuation order and 500 were on evacuation alert. B.C. Premier Christy Clark toured the Pemberton area with firefighters, and compared their job to playing chess.

"The difference is when you're playing a chess game with a forest fire, your opponent cheats. They don't play by the rules."

Another 240 soldiers from Edmonton were also in Saskatchewan helping with logistics. The military has said 500 more from Shilo, Man., were on standby.

Wildfire expert Mike Flannigan said tinderbox conditions that have lead to the fires can be blamed on climate change.

"Our weather this year has been very hot, dry and windy," said the University of Alberta professor. "This is consistent with what we expect with climate change."

urn:contentItem:5T8C-CSX1-F103-34Y9-00000-00HVAC system filters choked by smoke2018-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:40ZLexisNexisNEWSHVAC system filters choked by smoke

With a thick layer of smoke covering the province for a large part of the summer, experts are warning residents to clean the furnace and ducts in their homes and change the filters in their homes and cars more often.

Related: Okanagan air quality at a high health risk

Related: Air quality improves slightly

"With the forest fire smoke in the area it is more important than ever to replace filters," said Neil Grant, Modern Purair expert. "It should be changed out every three months under normal circumstances with more frequent replacement necessary under current conditions. Now that the smoke seems to have cleared, there are things homeowners can do to ensure they are breathing clean air in their homes."

Enrique Quesada is the manager of Vernon Modern Purair franchise and said he considers HVAC systems — including furnaces, air conditioners, duct work — the lungs of the building.

"The furnace constantly 'breathing in' and 'breathing out' while the system is operating, which you are then 'breathing in' and 'breathing out'," he said. "The furnace is the lungs of the entire system and the idea is that the "fresh" air outside be recycled and repurposed inside. The issue with the filters right now is that with all this smoke, the filters are getting entirely dirty. If the filter is plugged in, the smoke gets in that way and actually contaminates the inside."

He said that he, as a professional working in the industry, is seeing these problems continue, and even increase now that it's getting colder. He said that with smoke from the summer months now lodged in the furnace, it forces the motor to work harder, ultimately making it more vulnerable to break in the future.

Throughout much of the summer — up until mid-August — air quality across B.C. was at times considered a high health risk, ranking up to a nine on the Air Quality Health Index, a scale that shows the health risk associated with the air pollution we breathe.

urn:contentItem:5X4V-HD71-JDH1-C34G-00000-00Pellet plant coping with Canfor production reduction2019-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:40ZLexisNexisNEWSPellet plant coping with Canfor production reduction

The Houston Pellet Plant has so far been able to find enough material to fill the gap caused by the Canfor mill's temporary closures which began late last year, a challenge that will continue as the mill is now shifting to a four-day week schedule.

"We have been able to find fibre to keep the plant at full production but it has meant transitioning from sawmill residuals to harvest residuals. We are chipping low grade logs that cannot be used as sawlogs, cant logs or pulp logs," says Jason Fisher, a vice president of PinnaclePellet, a 30 per cent owner of the plant and its operator.

He said the need to find sources other than sawmill waste is company-wide as mills across B.C. have either closed outright or have been curtailing operations.

"This is a challenge that we have been addressing across BC in response to curtailments and closures. We have filled the gap in our supply by using more harvest residuals vs. sawmill residuals during this period," Fisher added.

"It is important to note that Houston Pellet is a partnership between Pinnacle Renewable Energy and Canfor and Canfor has been working with us to mitigate the impact of their schedule changes."

Fisher did say the search for material for the pellet plant has meant going farther afield than previously.

"During the first half of 2019, our team has more than tripled deliveries of harvest biomass (such as forest fire damaged or beetle killed trees, tree tops and limbs) to our B.C. facilities in response to curtailments," he said.

"While the sawmill curtailments have been impactful, our long-term fibre procurement strategy has ensured that we are able to continue consistent operation of all facilities."

Opened in 2007, the plant has been primarily feeding off the residuals of Canfor's sawmill located next door. It's 60 per cent owned by Canfor and 10 per cent by the MoricetownIndian Band.

Its annual production capacity is 230,000 metric tonnes, requiring the same quantity of oven-dried tonnes of biomass which is then compressed into pellets.

Pinnacle Renewable Energy is the third largest company of its kind in world and now has eight pellet-producing plants in western Canada with the first one being in Quesnel and the latest opening in Smithers last year. It also has one plant in Alabama.

Pinnacle's customers use the pellets to fire large-scale thermal power generation plants.

The company's shift to fibre from logging sites comes at a time when the provincial governmnet has been mandating that far less waste be left once merchantable timber is removed.

It is now charging triple stumpage, the fee to log Crown timber, on any wood left behind that is deemed to be economically viable.

"The key is ensuring that those policy changes are applied where there is an economic analysis that it's economical to bring that wood out," said forests minister Doug Donaldson in a recent interview.

urn:contentItem:5X4D-JV91-JDH1-C1T7-00000-00B.C. communities protest transfer of aid funds to those hit by sawmill closures2019-09-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:40ZLexisNexisBUSINESSB.C. communities protest transfer of aid funds to those hit by sawmill closuresTom Fletcher

The B.C. government's decision to transfer its $25 million annual "rural dividend fund" to an aid package for communities losing their sawmills has prompted a backlash.

The fund was set up by the B.C. Liberal government to provide economic diversification to communities of 15,000 population or smaller, many of them dependent on a single industry. That changed Sept. 17 when Forests Minister Doug Donaldson announced ministry funds have been reallocated for this year.

B.C. Liberal leader Andrew Wilkinson hosted rural community representatives at the Union of B.C. Municipalities convention Tuesday, where they took turns blasting the decision.

Williams Lake Mayor Walt Cobb said his community was counting on funds to help upgrade its water system.

Cobb noted the city is currently on a water quality advisory due to levels of manganese found in the water which does not meet Health Canada's new water quality guidelines.

"We can't wait two years," Cobb said.

Wilkinson said the current year's rural fund has 338 applications, totalling $35 million in needed assistance. The province has $300 million that was "left on the table" after a calm forest fire season, and that money should be available to help with rural needs whether they are related to mill closures or not, he said.

The new assistance fund is $69 million over two years, directed to four B.C. Interior communities that have seen a permanent closure or indefinite curtailment of mills: Quesnel, Chasm, Vavenby and Fort St. James.

RELATED: Teal-Jones shuts down remaining B.C. coast logging work

Port McNeill had an application in for the earlier fund, and Mayor Gaby Wickstrom was first to speak out publicly about the decision to defer applications to next year.

Part 1 - Listening to Minister Donaldson answer questions at the @truckloggerBC's dinner. Not quite understanding why Rural Dividend Funds needed to be redirected to address the Interior Forestry crisis. Those communities need both funding pools. #bcpoli #ubcm— Gaby Wickstrom (@GabyWickstrom) September 24, 2019

"Rural communities are going to keep knocking on the minister's door until someone realizes the reallocation of the rural dividend funds has been a big mistake," Wickstrom tweeted from the UBCM convention.

Donaldson sent letters to applicants for the rural dividend fund on the day the sawmill relief fund was announced, advising them their grant applications are "suspended until further notice" to help those hardest hit by a wave of mill closures across the Interior.

"I recognize the importance of this program and the services it supports," Donaldson said in the letter. "Staff are working with colleagues across other ministries to identify options for alternative funding, with an emphasis on community economic development and diversification."

Donaldson said projects funded through rural dividend funds in previous years are unaffected, and "all funded applicants are encouraged to continue to implement projects and complete the necessary reporting requirements."

(CP) - Residents of a small British Columbia city were put on evacuation alert Thursday as a growing forest fire came within a few hundred metres of their homes.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire outside Penticton, population 27,000, grew overnight to between 150 and 200 hectares from 24 hectares Wednesday evening.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"An evacuation plan is in place, but it's not imminent,'' Laverne Cormier, spokeswoman with the Penticton Forest District, said Thursday.</p><p>"This is a safety precaution - we certainly don't want to alarm people.''</p><p>Casey Saliken, whose home is nestled in the woods about 400 metres across the Ellis Creek canyon from the blaze, was among dozens of onlookers watching aerial tankers dump retardant on the fire.</p><p>Although the cause of the fire wasn't known, she believes it started near a dam on the creek.</p><p>"I hiked up there when it was still small and it was just past the dam where it started,'' she said.</p><p>"The water bombers scouted it out and it seemed so innocuous and then half an hour later it just exploded.''</p><p>Saliken was worried because she has no direct water to her home. As she spoke, her three horses neighed apprehensively, pacing back and forth in their nearby pen.</p><p>"If the wind kicked up now, it'd sure be scary,'' she said. "I've hiked quite a bit in that area and it's covered with old man's beard (dead brush) which would burn easily.''</p><p>Cormier said Thursday the front of the fire to the south was starting to pick up and ground crews were trying to block it.</p><p>The northeast corner was the most active, with fire climbing up the hill and away from homes.</p><p>"I doubt the fire will be contained today, more likely tomorrow, but it really depends on the weather,'' she said.</p><p>About 100 firefighters from forest district units in Vernon, Princeton and Kamloops were on the scene early, with more being called in.</p><p>Besides the water bombers, firefighters are using helicopters equipped with buckets and crews that can drop by rope from helicopters into inaccessible places.</p><p>Bright orange flames were visible from everywhere in the southern Okanagan city Wednesday night as people stopped to watch the water bombers attack the blaze.</p><p>Roadblocks were set up to limit traffic into threatened areas.</p><p>Dennis Gaudry, Ministry of Forests resource protection officer, said the steep, rocky terrain added to the difficulties of controlling the fire.</p><p>Winds were calm Thursday but the weather remained hot and dry.</p><p>The recent heat wave has dried up forests and sagebrush throughout the southern Interior, from Kamloops to the Canada-U.S. border.</p><p>Campfire bans were ordered for much of the region as dry lightning was predicted for the Okanagan today.</p><p>Near Kamloops, eight hectares burned in the Dew Drop area Tuesday from a human-caused fire, said Tracy Hendry, Kamloops Forest District fire control officer.</p><p>Last Saturday, 77 hectares between Valleyview and Juniper Ridge were scorched by some teens playing with matches. Crews were still tackling hot spots on Wednesday, Hendry said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7Y18-SSD1-2R4S-J19S-00000-00Discovery Air's Hicks & Lawrence Subsidiary Awarded 5-Year Fire Services Contract by Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources2010-03-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:40ZLexisNexisAttention Business EditorsDiscovery Air's Hicks & Lawrence Subsidiary Awarded 5-Year Fire Services Contract by Ontario Ministry of Natural ResourcesYELLOWKNIFE, NT March 15

Discovery Air Inc. announced today that its Hicks & Lawrence subsidiary has signed a new five year contract with the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources (OMNR) to provide twenty aircraft in support of the OMNR's forest fire management and air transport/utility requirements. Tom Ball, the OMNR's Provincial Aerial Operations Coordinator, commented that "Hicks & Lawrence was successful in obtaining a 5 year contract to provide Forest Fire Birddog, Aerial Fire Detection and Transport Services. They have been able to adapt to changing operational standards over the years and the serviceability of their aircraft continues to meet the high standards established by both Hicks & Lawrence and the Crown."

"We are extremely pleased with this contract award, which attests to our long-term track record in meeting the OMNR's needs and to our continuing ability to provide our customers, including the OMNR, with safe and professional air services," noted Mark Hill, Hicks & Lawrence's President. Discovery Air's President and CEO Dave Jennings commented that "This contract award is a great example of how Discovery Air develops profitable solutions that meet its customers' objectives. The renewal contract ensures that the Province of Ontario will continue to benefit from the full-time commitment of a team of experienced Hicks & Lawrence personnel and aircraft to meet provincial forest fire management requirements in a cost-effective manner. From Discovery Air's perspective, it provides enhanced revenue certainty for Hicks & Lawrence while still leaving upside potential depending on fire conditions."

Hicks & Lawrence is organized into two divisions, Fire and Air Charter. The Fire division is a primary supplier of Airborne Fire Management services to the OMNR. The Air Charter division provides charter services to various government agencies and corporate customers throughout Northern Ontario and Eastern Manitoba.

Discovery Air Inc., founded in 2004, is a specialty aviation company that operates across Canada and in select locations internationally. With 145 aircraft, Discovery Air is the second largest air operator in Canada. Discovery Air's 500 person team provides unique flying solutions to a variety of government and business customers. Through its five operating companies, DA offers fixed-wing and rotary-wing services as well as logistics and remote operations management. Services include vital air ambulance operations, cargo and passenger operations to remote areas of northern Canada, utility flying for mining and oil and gas exploration, forest fire detection and airspace management, and airborne training and special mission services to the Canadian Army, Navy and Air Force.

Discovery Air's shares and debentures trade on the Toronto Stock Exchange (Symbols DA.A and DA.DB respectively).

urn:contentItem:4SR0-3YH0-TX4V-K184-00000-00Forest fire burns railway bridge, cutting off supply route for Manitoba community2008-06-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:04:40ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSForest fire burns railway bridge, cutting off supply route for Manitoba communityCP

WINNIPEG _ A remote community in northern Manitoba is running out of food and other necessities after forest fires destroyed a railway bridge, cutting off its access to the outside world.

There's only two ways into Pukatawagan in the summer _ by air or by rail.

The two stores in Pukatawagan have flown in supplies, but not in quantities large enough for the community.

A week ago, a fire burning near Sherridon destroyed the wooden bridge.

Resident Joyce Bear, 50, says people take the train to The Pas once a month to get food and other items.

She says the local store has run out of basic necessities such as milk, eggs and fresh produce, and gasoline is being kept for emergency vehicles only.

Pukatawagan is an isolated community of about 1,500 people near the Manitoba-Saskatchewan boundary, about 850 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg.

Via Rail Canada runs a train twice a week on the 200-kilometre stretch of line between The Pas and Pukatawagan, under an agreement with Keewatin Railway Co., a firm owned by a First Nations consortium. KRC owns and maintains the track.

Tom McCahill, general manager for KRC, said that more than 25 metres of track across a small creek needs rebuilding. The site will be examined by an engineering firm to estimate the cost of rebuilding the bridge, but only when the firm can get to the location, McCahill said.

In the meantime, KRC will temporarily patch the track, laying lines across steel culvert and earth fill, he said. He estimated patching work will take a couple of days but can't start until work crews can get to the site.

Until the track repairs are done, the Northern Store and a local co-op in Pukatawagan have been bringing in food and supplies by plane. The co-op, the People's Store, has increased prices to cover the higher freight costs.

Pukatawagan Chief Shirley Castel said the people can't afford the increases in the price of food.

''Most of them have spent their welfare issuance already because of the high cost of food,'' Castel said.

The Northern Store hasn't increased prices but can't bring in enough to serve the community.

''We brought in dry goods and perishable foods a couple of days ago, but we've already run out,'' said Brian McKay, grocery manager at the Northern Store.

McKay said Northern executives in Winnipeg have told him not to increase prices, but he doesn't know how long that policy will remain in place if the railroad bridge isn't fixed soon.

(Winnipeg Free Press)

Thurber would not comment on rumours that the fire began when debris was being burned at a home construction site.</p><p>Constantly shifting winds throughout the night forced continual reassessment of the situation.</p><p>About 800 people evacuated from their homes late Wednesday are expected to learn later in the day whether it is safe for them to return. "What we're trying to do is get ahead of the thing to find out where it's going.''</p><p>Large plumes of smoke hung over the area about 20 minutes outside Halifax as officials went-door-to-door to evacuate homes.</p><p>Officials set up accommodations in a school for anyone unable to stay with friends or relatives.</p><p>The fire burned to within 60 metres of some homes shortly after the fire began in the afternoon. One resident who had been asked to leave his home said flames were shooting up to 10 metres in the air.</p><p>More than 100 RCMP and police officers manned barricades, directing traffic or helping in the evacuation effort.</p><p>Salvation Army volunteers carted food and drink to weary firefighters.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata
